title: The ADC Problem: Why ADCs aren't the actual problem.
body:
Now, before you downvote, hear me out.

The problem isn't ADCs being OP or ADC itemization being obscenely good. (Yeah, some ADC items are broken but that's not the point). Rather, ADCs are being picked left-and-right in all lanes because their specialization, item diversity and sheer choices are through the roof and more in line with where Riot wants to take league.

To further understand this, we have to go back to the ADC itemization/Mass ADC update. Now, yes, there are champions who are better and were broken on launch, but the real thing this did was give ADCs powerful niches and items to compensate for any shortcoming or to enhance their own abilities. As a quick example, let's say I'm playing Caitlyn.

What do I have that I can buy in terms of how I customize my way-of-play?

* {{item:3031}} to increase my raw damage output.
* {{item:3508}} to increase my ability strength.
* {{item:3094}} to give me stronger sieging poke.
* {{item:3046}} to benefit my dueling potential.
* {{item:3036}} to deal with high HP and high armor units.

You get the idea. I have tons of options to edit and customize my playstyle. While there are some items that are better for some champions, one cannot deny that most, if not all, of these items have some level of usefulness. 

Now, let's say I'm playing Malzahar. What options do I have?

* {{item:3089}} for raw power.
* {{item:3116}} for power and health.
* {{item:3151}} for high HP (Although it doesn't work great and only excels when paired with rylais)
* {{item:3157}} for power and defense.

I could go on but I think the point is clear. If it isn't: When I play an AP character, my options are far more limited in scope. Customizing build usually only gives me one path. If I want to burn high HP targets, I generally have to grab Rylais AND Liandries when an ADC only need Dominiks. If I want ability spam, I generally need to invest 2-3 items in just CDR when an ADC can get that much through one item and maybe boots/runes. etc etc etc.

Now, you'll likely go "Wow so unfair nerf ADC items" but hold the horses. This is where Riot WANTS the game to go. In a perfect world, every class would have itemization options like ADCs and every tank, fighter, mage and support would have the clearest cut of roles. Are ADCs a problem? Yes, because you're comparing a 2016 product to a 2013 product. Even the small item changes Riot does make to other roles, while good on paper, don't mend the problem as they should.

I'm not going to try and defend Riot's speed on implementing these changes. If anything, a speed like this will leave some classes far too much in the dust to justify what they actually need right now. However, I will say that complaining about ADCs right now isn't really the issue. You may disagree with me but what I think is that we need to bring OTHER classes to the level ADCs have, not blindly nerf ADCs so that they fall in line with the old and outdated products.

i think the inherent nature of ADC's require their items to be more diverse. They are almost by definition right click bots. And so you need to be able to diversify how you right click. The only way to do this is with items. 

Mages are spell casters by definition - and so their kits (Q,W,E,R) define their playstyle - more than their items. 

For example, you could build {{champion:29}} with {{item:3153}} {{item:3046}} so that he can duel people or {{item:3031}} {{item:3094}} so he can assassinate people.

When you pick {{champion:7}} you are already predefined as a burst assassin not a tanky dps because of her kit. And so {{item:3116}} {{item:3027}} doesn't make any sense.

Somewhat. Part of that is what I assume the mage update to be and split up champions in the mage field away from the traditional push/poke/burst that seems to be all their good at.

However, I feel that mage itemization can be diverse, it just can't be as "simple" as ADC's. As an example, most ADC itemization falls into crit or on-hit. Mage itemization, by comparison, should have more actives and passive abilities. I think the Black Market Brawler items [(Seen here)](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Black_Market_Brawlers) could serve as great basis for iteration and itemization.

I think that the things we have are good. We just need more options.

Liandry's damage is minimal unless your target has both high HP and low MR. Chances are they have high MR if they have high HP, so you need void staff to actually make it work. As stated by the OP, its heavy synergy with Rylai's (and also DoTs) means it's not a complete item on its own.

Lich Bane does not work on its own, it needs a lot of AP to scale. Overall, while it does tend to try and fill a tower killing niche, its power level is not high enough to warrant buying it unless your kit has heavy synergy with it (see Ziggs). It's mostly a burst enhancer for assassins. If it's supposed to help kill towers, it should give you some incentive to use its damage against towers.

Morellonomicon tries to do many different things and kinda fails at all of them. High AP? Not really, 80 is on the low side. High CDR? Yes, but you need mana to make that work and... it's mana regen alone is good, but not good enough. The grievous wound is very hard to trigger compared to Mortal Reminder. 

Seraph's is a very strong item, however you need to stack it to actually access the active, so the accessibility is heavily gated. It also fills 3 niches that don't quite go together. One is a heavy mana item, another is a high AP item and the third one is a survivability item. This, plus the fact that you need to be able to fill it up quickly means it's an EXTREMELY niche item.

Zhonya's active is good, but it's actually killing diversity AND the item's actual power.

Banner is arguably not a mage item and more of an AP scaling support item.

{{champion:67}} %Max hp true damage is an extremely toxic mechanic that doesn't belong in the game.

%max hp true damage isn't a toxic concept. Hell, I'm not even going to expand on that because I shouldn't have to. Certain implementations of that mechanic can be bullshit, but she has to hit you 3 times in a row, without opportunity to switch targets, if she wants that true damage. Complaining about Vayne's true damage at this point is pretty pointless. It's probably the most fair way of adding the damage type, because she's all about sustained damage and that forces her into that pattern if she wants to use the mechanic.

I think the %Max Health true damage is not toxic itself, what makes it toxic is what's around it (huge mobility that makes it easy to proc or maybe some kind of long hard cc or even a combinatio of both like some small mobility boost like a ms boost paired with an average spammable slow). In Vayne's case it's that she can proc the 3 hits far too easily with too much safety since she can just aa-q-e you as early as level 3, meaning you CAN'T contest that most of the times and even when you should be able to, in the best case scenario you are just damaging her back trading damage for damage and hoping you hurt her more or at least have more sustain, this makes vayne pretty much a stat check like Xin Zhao, WW, Udyr, Volibear, Irelia most of the game but you also scale as an hypercarry so later on your stat check will ALWAYS be in your favour. Add the stun on the e that is far too easy to proc most of the times and you get why she's pretty toxic right now. If her E didn't apply stacks of silver bolts or wouldn't disable you for up to 2 seconds (at max range condemn can disable an opponent for 0.5 seconds from the knockback + 1.5 seconds from the stun) she would be more fair.
She's not unbalanced or broken or op, she's just a bit unfair to play against but far from op.
This is obviousyl my opinion, feel free to disagree.

Mages have just as many options as ADCs, but a lot of mages tunnel on what will give them the most oomph for their hit, just like how adcs ALWAYS get IE, a crit AS item, and a last whisper.

I'll play your game.

Ardent Censor has been complained about all the time. The only person that anyone thinks it's actually useful on is Alistar. It's incredibly niche, and there are so few people that can use it to do much of anything.

Archangel's Staff is a huge gamble; you never know if it's going to be useful before the end of the game. More games end early now in season 6 with the increased death timers and how devastating a little bit of AD is to a tower. I've seen tons of games where the adc or as assassin gets out of control around 18 minutes in, and then the game's over in 5 more minutes.

No one builds banner of command because it barely gives any AP, barely any teams are AP heavy these days, and most people buy Zz'rot instead, which hasn't established itself a nice little niche in any role.

Icebourn is way too overloaded to be considered just an AP option, and no one builds it on AP champions. A lot of AP champions don't have autos in their combos. The most popular person to use this item is Ezreal, and ADC, or any number of tanks that can really get in close to use the aoe slow.

Luden's serves pretty much the same purpose as shiv or runaan's, to spread your damage out.

Lich bane is very niche, and just a bit more common on mages than icebourn

Rabadon's is essentially the equivalent of I.E. for ADC's

Will of the Ancients? Really? I don't think even Vlad builds that very often. Most people who benefit from it build Gunblade before even thinking about it. To make it do much of anything, you need to have insane burst, which you usually get by being ahead. If you're ahead, you need sustain less than when you're behind. Most people need to build Zhonia's to not die before ever considering Will of the Ancients.

You want to talk about limited options? The one thing that everyone can recommend you build on mages is the fucking trinity of AP items, Luden's, Rabadon's, And Zhonia's. That's it. That's 3 things you can expect a mage to build every time, and they're probably going to. Without these items, they're mostly worthless. I mean, you have RoA, which I'll admit is a good item, but other than that, ADC's have so many different choices to do a lot of the same things.

If you want Lifesteal, you have BT, Black Cleaver, Mercurial Scimitar, Death's Dance, and Blade of the Ruined King.

If you want magic resist, you have Maw, Mercurial Scimitar, Wit's End, and Guardian Angel. I could cite Dervish Blade here, but I'm not because I know that no one buys it.

If you want crit, you've got Infinity Edge, Phantom Dancer, Rapid Fire Cannon, Statikk Shiv, Triforce, Essence Reaver, and Runaan's Hurricane.

The list goes on and on. AP may be everywhere, but mages don't have a valid form of "lifesteal" to work with. Spell Vamp is pretty god-awful unless you're Vlad or Akali, who last I checked builds hybrid anyway.

If you want armor as a mage, you can only really get Zhonia's, maybe Icebourn Gauntlet, but we've discussed how very niche that item is, and also Frozen Heart, which will totally cripple your damage.

We have two options for health regen of pretty much any kind, both of which make your damage output pretty pathetic, and one is a hybrid item that you probably want for an active slow than anything else.

Mages also have no tank buster items. Liandry's Torment and Void Staff don't help all that much on someone with 6000 health anyway, even if you could completely ignore their magic resist.

I could do a huge thread just talking about how much more valid AD's options are over AP's options. Most of the examples that everyone is using is totally irrelevant or so much of a niche item you might as well not bother unless you are one of a very select few champions.

You literally just defined power creep.

Somewhat. 

Power Creep, at least to me, is when old elements of the game are left in the dust because of newer elements. You see this in hearthstone where certain things just outclass and overwrite anything done before. Rather, what Riot is trying to do is power normalization. They don't want to make one aspect better, they want to normalize things and bring everyone up to a better level.

Now, are they doing a good job of this? Well....eh.

> Now, are they doing a good job of this? Well....eh.

I'll boldly answer that question for you: no.

Not because the balance is bad, but because Riot is taking **far** too long to bring other classes up to marksman levels. I know better than anyone that Riot moves at a snail's pace, but we've gone _months_ with one class being elevated over the others simply because they got to go first.

It's great if all the classes eventually get to where marksmen are now, but in the meantime things are going to be shoddy. And with what we know of Riot, that length of that meantime is months, if not years. That is completely unacceptable.

No, it is when every update increases damage output, mobility and other stats in an infinite loop. AD champions being RELATIVELY strong is less of an issue. AD champions being ABSOLUTELY disgustingly strong is the problem. Are you happy with how turrets die in 3 seconds? AD overall needs toning down, then AP rework needs to keep champions' strength at the same level as it is now while adding variety.
"Bringing everyone up to a better level" is a correct perception of what is happening, but increasing everybody's strength is just not healthy for the game balance.

Champions from other seasons were examples of this, some outright being better in every way than older ones. However, ADC changes didn't outright "make these characters better", they redefined and reworked their niches. Were some characters better? Power Creep would be taking the mage update and making them flat-out better than the ADCs. If that does happen then yeah, that's an issue of PC but ADCs being redefined as a whole isn't power creep.

And Malzahar is a bad example to bring up because, quite frankly, he is a rare exception amongst mages when it comes to builds. You can build almost any type of AP itemization on Malzahar because his kit allows it. His ratios, his % damage, DoTs, mana costs, etc. all aid in this.

Let me give you some examples of poor itemization choices that AP mages have.

1. {{item:3153}} and {{item:3151}} . Liandrys' gives health, AP, and magic pen. And a HP% damage DoT that requires another component not found in the item to be entirely useful, thus the emphasis on {{item:3116}} . That's two item slots in order to get the best effect from this item. Now look at BotRK; it gives AD, Attack Speed, Lifesteal, gives HP% on-hit that ALSO heals, and has an active effect that slows, deals HP% damage, and heals. Requires no other items to get the best use of this. It is a one-slot wonder.

2. {{item:3156}} and {{item:3157}} . Both try to give the same thing; power with a mix of defensive stats. Hourglass gives flat AP and a small amount of armor, with a stasis active. The active in itself is a powerful tool, but also conditional. Other than that, it only gives two stats. Now let's look at {{item:3156}} . It gives AD, Magic Resist, _and_ a way to penetrate Hourglass' armor with its armor pen. As well as two passives, a shield and a steroid, which require no real pre-meditated usage, and are otherwise non-conditional boosts in power. If Hourglass had a MR-pen stat added to it, it may be more in line with Maw.

3. {{item:3285}} and {{item:3087}} / {{item:3094}} . Both supply similar passive effects; you move and cast abilities/attack more, you get more charges to do more damage. They both provide movement speed to help build those stacks faster, but that's about all that Luden's has going for it. It has no CDR or mana regen to help an AP caster build it up faster in combat, while Statikk and Rapidfire both have Attack Speed added onto them to make the charges come up faster. Luden's, thus, requires another CDR/Mana Regen item to make it more effective. A 2 item-slot requirement. Again, ADC raw stats beat AP itemization.

Clear statistics don't go for bias, my friend.
